The PSM Program Guidelines serve as a reference manual, providing facility team members, both executives and hourlyÂ¿s, specific procedures for implementing the program.  In general, element guidelines describe the following:

Â¿ 	Functions of individual elements.
Â¿ 	Repeatable processes to be followed.
Â¿ 	Utilization of employee resources.
Â¿ 	Contingency plans for emergencies.
Â¿ 	Measures to be used for evaluating the effectiveness of the program.
Â¿ 	Method to evaluate risk associated with ammonia refrigeration systems.
Â¿ 	Maintenance and update of PSM elements.
Â¿ Provisions for feedback and continuous improvement.

The program is complex and has been developed by integrating facility safety programs with maintenance management, facility operations, and human resources management.

At the Lake City Food Distribution Center T-3892, Target is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program, covering design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with our regulated process.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, Target has proactively partnered with Lake CityÂ¿s Fire Department to provide properly trained and equipped hazmat responders that are available to control and mitigate the effects of a release.   We also will coordinate such events with North Central Florida Regional Planning Council, FL, the local emergency planning commission that services Columbia County for additional support.

2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

This facility is a refrigerated warehouse facility

.  The vast majority of products stored is refrigerated foods for human consumption and inherently pose no known environmental or safety risks.  The RMP regulated substance present at the facility is anhydrous ammonia, utilized as refrigerant in closed-loop refrigeration systems.  

Ammonia is expected to be added into the system in excess of the threshold reporting quantity in mid April 2008.   The amount of ammonia estimated to be in the system is 42,000 pounds.   
Based on the size and characteristics of our ammonia system, as well as Process Safety Management (PSM) applicability, this facility is covered under Program 3 of the RMP regulations.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Necessary processes to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 have been implemented and are ongoing.  The facility is also subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119, as well as the EPCRA Section 302 and 311/312 notification/reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the accidental release prevention program that are in place at our facility.

Process Safety Information (PSI) - 

The newly developed Process Safety Information Guideline contains an inventory list of necessary documents that are in place as of March 2008.  This information will be revised as the newly installed ammonia refrigeration system is put into operation.  This data contains detailed safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.

Process Hazard Analysis -

A Process Hazard Analysis PSM Guideline and full PHA study for the refrigeration system was completed in March 2008.  The methodology used was the What If Scenarios.  Representatives from Target, Ryan Companies US, Inc. (Refrigeration Contractor), and Hixson (Refrigeration Consultant) with expertise in

refrigeration engineering and operations participated in the study.

The adopted PHA Guideline calls for studies to be reevaluated at a minimum of every five (5) years and any findings related to process hazard analysis studies to be addressed in a timely manner.  

Operating Procedures -

An Operating Procedures PSM Guideline was completed in March 2008 which defines the processes for drafting, validating, and maintaining written operating procedures, including annual reviews.  Safe Operating Procedures are in place that address necessary modes of operation including startup, normal operations, emergency operations, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, and pump out.

Training -

New Training PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008, defining training programs for employees working with the ammonia refrigeration systems to increase competence in all relevant operating procedures.  Refresher training is specified to take place at a minimum every three (3) years, and more frequently, as needed.

Mechanical Integrity -

The Mechanical Integrity PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008.  Maintenance operations are being carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in ammonia refrigeration system maintenance practices.  

Any equipment deficiencies identified by ongoing maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change -

The Management of Change PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008. The guideline defines procedures that are in place to manage changes in the ammonia system's technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by an ammonia system modification are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Pre-Startup Reviews -

The Pre-Startup Review PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008.  The guideline stipulates that Pre-start up safety reviews are conducted any time the ammonia refrigeration system or any of its compo

nents are opened to atmosphere for repairs, tie-ins, or modifications.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction is complete, documentations still accurate, operating procedures in place, training is complete and safety pre-cautions are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. 

Compliance Audits -

New Compliance Audit PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008.  The guideline specifies process and frequency for evaluation of PSM and RMP program effectiveness.  These audits are to be carried out at least every three (3) years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  

In that this is a newly constructed facility, a compliance audit has not been conducted to date.  

Incident Investigation -
 
New Incident Investigation PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008 and describes processes to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, an unintentional release of ammonia.  These investigations are to identify situations leading to incidents, as well as corrective actions implemented to prevent reoccurring and future releases, with reports retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

Employee Participation -

New Employee Participation PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008 and describes employee utilization in the development and implementation of the facility's PSM and RMP programs.  In addition the guideline identifies employee orientation, training and communication processes to be followed for educating employees about the hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia, and safety programs in place to mitigate risks of injury and accidental release to atmosphere.  This includes processes for making all PSM and RMP information related to implementation, including Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) information, readily accessible for employee use. 

Company employees are encouraged to report unsafe conditions, express their views concerning ac

cident prevention issues, and recommend improvements. 

Contractors -

New Contractors PSM Guideline was adopted March 2008.  On occasion, outside contractors will be utilized to conduct specialized maintenance and/or construction activities related to the ammonia refrigeration system.  

The new Contractors Guideline mandates a pre-qualification process which includes evaluation of contractor safety records, documented understanding of the facility's work rules, and commitment to ongoing training of their employeesÂ¿ as related to the hazards associated with ammonia refrigeration systems.  We are committed to continually informing and up-dating contractors regarding known potential hazards related to work with ammonia systems, and the facility's procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of ammonia occur.

4. Five-year Accident History

This is the initial RMP submittal.  

5. Emergency Response Plan

New Emergency Action Plan PSM Guideline was  adopted March 2008.  The Emergency Action Plan identifies specific procedures to be implemented in the event of various emergencies, including an ammonia release.  The Emergency Action Plan addresses adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

This is a new ammonia refrigeration system.  All manufacturer safety precautions have been built into the system.

Lake City, Florida 32055

Risk Management Plan Â¿ Ammonia Refrigeration System - 42,000 Pounds

Executive Summary

TargetÂ¿s Lake City, Florida Food Distribution Center T3892 is a newly constructed facility.  This facility is a refrigerated warehouse for the storage and distribution of perishable and frozen food products.   Ammonia will be first introduced to the system in early April of 2008.  Ryan Companies US, Inc. is responsible for construction, startup, daily maintenance, and operation of the facility up until June 1, at which point the system will be turned over to Target Corporation.

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Target recognizes that accidents involving our ammonia refrigeration systems or other facility equipment cannot be prevented by technology-oriented solutions alone.  Safety must be a constant daily concern. Like any other aspect our business, safety must be actively managed and monitored. 

The Â¿initialÂ¿ Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Plan (RMP) in development (April /May 2008) will be living documents, defining the administrative and operational processes to be utilized during and after the facilityÂ¿s turn over, June 1, 2008.  Target also reserves the right to modify and adapt itsÂ¿ PSM and RMP plans as appropriate to address changes in our business processes, as well as things deemed ineffective. The overall intent of these programs are to minimize or eliminate the following potential threats for achieving a safe work place and zero refrigerant releases:

Â¿ 	Human error in operating or maintaining ammonia refrigeration systems. 
Â¿ 	Human error when working around or near ammonia refrigeration system components.
Â¿ 	Lack of knowledge regarding ammonia refrigeration systems and their inherent hazards.
Â¿ 	Inappropriate response to incidents involving ammonia refrigeration systems.
